title: Sri Lanka’s forex woes affect issuance of driver’s licenses
body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s prevailing foreign exchange shortage has adversely affected the issuance of driver’s licenses, with the authorities unable to import plastic cards to print licenses on.

Commissioner General of Motor Traffic Sumith Alahakoon told EconomyNext that the cards are imported from Austria and that, dude to the ongoing forex shortages, it is difficult to open the required letters of credit (LCs).

He said the government has temporarily extended the validity period of a driving license for one year. Meanwhile, licenses that expire between April 01 and June 30 will be valid for six months, while licenses that expire between July 01 and September 30 will be extended for three months,.
Temporary licenses issued via the postal service can also be renewed within a year, he said, and once a consignment of cards is received, applicants will have their licenses posted to them by mail.
In January 2021, the Sri Lanka Army took over the running of databases of citizens authorized to drive and produce driving licenses.
“We are creating alternatives to ensure that no one in the public is adversely affected,” said Alahakoon.

An app will be launched for the police and other relevant authorities in Sri Lanka to maintain law and order on the roads. The mechanism will also use the National Identity Card (NIC) to verify the license holder, the official said. (Colombo/Mar03/2022)
